In ANJI we have an option to enable/disable recurrent connections. 
The way=
 we determine if a connection is "backward" is by checking for
a loop every=
 time we add a new connection.

I'm pretty sure this is the way Ken's code =
does it, too.  If you're
connecting nodes A & B, then start with B and trav=
erse the net to see
if you connect to A.  If you do, disallow the connectio=
n.

On 11/1/05, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
>
> It turns out =
that supporting feed-forward networks isn't as easy as I'd
> hoped. I naive=
ly assumed that if I modified the 'add connection' routine
> to only add co=
nnections where the source neuron's innovation # was less
> than the target=
's [with a bit of added complexity around the input and
> output neurons] t=
hat this would do the job.
>
> Unfortunately I noticed that some connection=
s were still going back into
> the net. This of course is due to the way we=
 add new neurons by
> splitting connections, which means that new neurons w=
ith high innovation
> #'s are placed throughout the network and often befor=
e neurons with
> lower innov #'s. It seems obvious to me now of course :)
>=

> So it seems I need some other mechanism to ensure new conenctions are
> =
all feed-forward and because of the optimisations in my exiting genome
> co=
de it is now quite rigid, or at least if I start hacking around in
> there =
I risk disturbing the optimsations. No I think I'll defer this
> work for n=
ow, what I want to do is allow for easy plugging-in of
> alternative genome=
 classes which is something not quite in place right
> now. However, as par=
t of this I want to do a more wide ranging change
> which would be to expan=
d the ANN model in use to allow for neurons with
> multiple incoming connec=
tions. The standard single connection point
> neurons then just become a sp=
ecial case (I think!).
>
> Of course that could potentially take a while so=
 I'll be thinking about
> wrapping up everything I've done to-date and rele=
asing some code in the
> next day or so.
>
> Colin.
